thread.title: Storm Doris causes travel chaos with flights cancelled and thousands left without power as UK weather sees 87mph winds
thread.title_full: Storm Doris causes travel chaos with flights cancelled and thousands left without power as UK weather sees 87mph winds

author: lburnip
title: Storm Doris causes travel chaos with flights cancelled and thousands left without power as UK weather sees 87mph winds
text:
Storm Doris (as shown in this graphic above heading towards the UK) is set to push in from the west on Thursday - bringing 80mph winds, heavy rain and even snow Alamy Severe fog and low visibility this morning over the Pontsticill Reservoir as the recent warm spell comes to an end Alamy The scene when heavy rain and strong winds whipped up the waves earlier this month in Newhaven, West Sussex Alamy A couple struggling with an umbrella in the strong breeze as heavy rain falls at West Bay in Dorset in January Dramatic video of Storm Doris waves as bad weather batters Dawlish coast 
There were concerns Doris would hit earlier this month but the weather never reached the threshold needed to be classified as a storm by the Met Office. 
Forecasters re-evaluated this position earlier today and announced Storm Doris had formed and was heading for the UK on Thursday, bringing with it snow, rain and 80mph winds. 
This time last year, the UK had already been hit by nine named storms but Doris is just the fourth - following Angus, Barbara and Conor. The Met Office only names storms when forecasters believe them to have the potential cause amber 'be prepared' or red 'take action' warnings and do this in order to make people more aware of sever weather. The stormy conditions follow a warm air blast from tropical America which pushed thermometers into double figures. 
Now the Met Office has issued warnings for snow and wind from the early hours of Thursday morning. 
The warnings state: "Snow is expected over high ground of northern England and Scotland on Thursday and may fall to low levels for a time in Scotland. 
"In addition, strong winds are expected to develop with gusts of 50 to 60 mph. This will result in drifting of the snow and blizzard conditions over high ground. Associated heavy rain at lower levels will be an additional hazard. 
"The combination of snow, strong winds and heavy rain is likely to lead to disruption to transport networks and perhaps power supplies." #StormDoris is going to push in from the west on Thursday, bringing very strong winds, heavy rain as well as some snowfall in the north pic.twitter.com/ZxeYNjQxW0 
— Met Office (@metoffice) February 21, 2017 ⚠️Snow is expected over high ground of N England and Scotland on Thursday and may fall to low levels for a time in Scotland #StormDoris ⚠️ pic.twitter.com/Rke7qsmC6V 
— Met Office (@metoffice) February 21, 2017 RELATED STORIES here comes the sun UK set for Caribbean heat blast this weekend making Britain hotter than Barcelona and Abu Dhabi CARIBBEAN VORTEX UK weather to get hotter than Abu Dhabi as Caribbean heat blast heads for Britain - but storms and snow will follow WHAT A DIFFERENCE A DAY MAKES Snow melts after Britain's big freeze... but downpours and gales set to return ARCTIC BLAST Snow and floods to hit UK again before weather gets sunnier - but will you escape the flurry? WINTER'S BACK! Will you see some snow? Here's what you need to know about the latest weather bomb 
The Met Office said that stronger winds may develop across parts of "northern England, northern Wales and the north Midlands". 
They added: "Some very strong winds are expected throughout Thursday in association with storm 'Doris', with a short period where gusts of 70 to 80 mph are possible. 
"Whilst the strongest winds look to be only short-lived, damage to structures, interruptions to power supplies and widespread disruption to travel networks are likely, with a danger of injury from flying debris."
